Award.AwardTitle: Conformational Equilibria of Biologically Relevant Oligosaccharides
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the human body, approximately half of all proteins are decorated with sugars. These hybrid structures are known as glycoproteins. Glycoproteins can be found inside cells, attached to their external surfaces (cell membranes) or in the extracellular space. There is increasing appreciation that the sugar component of these glycoproteins plays a crucial role in human health and disease, for example, in bacterial and viral infection, cancer, immunity, and diabetes. Efforts to understand these cellular processes depend upon knowledge of the chemical structures of the sugars on the protein, that is, what sugars are present, how they behave in three dimensions, and how their shapes change over time. This project will develop new analytical tools to investigate and assign sugar structure in solution. Students will be cross-trained in both experimental and theoretical methods ranging from chemical synthesis of sugars to advanced computational methods used to predict their molecular structures. The work aims to provide new crosstalk between experiment and theory, with the intent of refining both into more powerful tools to understand glycoprotein structure.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division and the Computational and Data-Enabled Sciences and Engineering Program is funding Drs. Anthony Serianni and Ian Carmichael of the University of Notre Dame, and Dr. Robert Woods of the University of Georgia, to develop new nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and computational tools to predict the three-dimensional structures and dynamics of the high-mannose and complex-type N-glycans of human glycoproteins. This research group will use redundant NMR J-couplings to experimentally determine conformational populations about the rotatable bonds comprising the O-glycosidic linkages in these N-glycans. To achieve this goal, computational methods (density functional theory) will be used to derive new equations that relate the magnitudes of specific J-couplings to specific torsion angles in the linkages. Armed with new experimental data on conformational populations, comparisons will be made between the experimental findings and theoretical conformational populations obtained from solvated molecular dynamics simulations, in an effort to validate the MD predictions or justify modifications in the equations underlying the MD method. The long-term goal is to determine the detailed structural properties of biologically important complex oligosaccharides, either free in solution or bound to proteins or lipids. This knowledge will prove valuable in understanding how N-glycans exert their myriad biological functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The biological functions of biomolecules are determined in large part by their three-dimensional shapes (conformations) in solution and in the bound state, the relative abundances of these conformations, and the rate at which these conformations interconvert.  Knowledge of these properties of a substrate in solution and bound to a protein receptor/enzyme is essential to the design of effective drugs that exhibit high selectivity and/or tight binding to the protein receptor/enzyme.

Sugar (saccharide) molecules present on the plasma and internal membranes of cells mediate many important biochemical processes, including cell-cell recognition, immunogenic response, and the binding of bacteria and viruses during infection.  These functions are influenced by saccharide conformation and flexibility, but experimental methods to characterize these structural properties have proven difficult to develop.  The current solution to this dilemma has been to develop and apply computational methods to predict the conformational behaviors of saccharides from theory, despite the fact that experimental data needed to test and validate these computed behaviors remain meager.  In essence, these computational tools are used despite the lack of adequate experimental validation.  A common computational tool is molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, which uses a set of equations (the force-field) to calculate, among other things, the relative abundances of saccharide conformations in solution and their rates of interconversion.  In many instances at present, MD is the only means to gain insight into saccharide conformation and flexibility, either free in solution or bound to protein receptors, because experimental data are either limited or unavailable.

This project aimed to solve the above problem by developing a new experimental method to assign saccharide conformation in solution that captures information on molecular flexibility and provides outputs that can be compared directly to those provided by MD simulation. This goal was achieved.  A new experimental method, called MA'AT analysis, was developed that produces explicit conformational models that can be superimposed directly on those obtained from MD simulation for comparison and validation.  The MA'AT method uses nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to measure a group (ensemble) of NMR parameters called J-couplings (scalar couplings), and treats this ensemble collectively using circular statistics and parameterized equations obtained from density functional theory (DFT) calculations, which relate each J-coupling to the same molecular torsion angle in the saccharide (redundant J-couplings).  The method provides three outputs:  (1) a mean value (or values) of preferred torsion angle(s); (2) circular standard deviations (CSDs) whose magnitudes reflect the mobility of the torsion angle or angles about their mean values (CSDs report on the flexibility of torsion angles); and (3) parameter space plots to determine the uniqueness of the fits (single-state models only).  During the course of the three-year project, two conformational elements in saccharides were investigated in detail by the MA'AT method:  (1) O-acetyl side-chain conformation (Figure 1); and (2) O-glycosidic linkage conformation (Figure 2).  In both cases, the MA'AT-derived models and those obtained by MD simulation were mostly in very close agreement, but in some cases the MA'AT results indicate that the force-field underpinning the MD simulations (in this case, GLYCAM6) is in need of revision.  The underlying MA'AT mathematics was encoded into a stand-alone, user-friendly software package that can be executed on a Mac or PC platform to allow use by the wider research community.  Since the MA'AT method of modeling molecular conformation is, in principle, applicable to any molecule that contains multiple J-couplings that are sensitive to the same molecular torsion angle, new opportunities exist to investigate not only saccharides but also a range of biomolecules, including oligopeptides and oligonucleotides. 

Towards the end of the project period, MA'AT analysis was extended to more complex problems in saccharide conformational analysis where multi-state models of molecular torsion angles pertain, including exocyclic side-chain conformation, five-membered ring conformation, and six-membered ring conformation.  In these more demanding tests of the method, much larger ensembles of redundant NMR J-couplings (up to 12 J-values, for example) could be measured, which allowed multi-state models of the torsion angles of interest to be tested.  MA'AT analysis was able to treat these behaviors remarkably well.  For example, the method has provided the first unbiased experimental model of the conformational behavior of the five-membered β-D-ribofuranosyl ring, a result of particular importance to structural studies of nucleic acids and other furanose ring-containing biomolecules.  Studies of saccharide ring conformation, and of more complex biologically relevant oligosaccharides, using MA'AT analysis are being conducted in a follow-up NSF-funded project (CHE 1707660) that is currently underway.
